10644157.review:
I have seen Indie Game: The Movie before on youtube, and I recently purchased it as part of the Indie Game: The Movie Bundle. The extra content paid for is pretty much commentary, extras, and a "Where's Waldo" style game; It may not be considered a "deal" if extra money is being paid for a free movie, but you can consider it as a way to support everyone involved in the movie, as well as the games the creators of the documentary wanted to include but didn't. That said, the movie is the most emotional documentary about independently developed video games.

You get to see part of the daily lives of independent game developers and their work lives, which means viewing, at the time, relatively no-name people with hardly a dollar to their name working months to years without any payment, crafting story, audio, visual, gameplay, debugging, and (because they're male) BEARDS! You also see the heartbreaking drama of program builds that won't run properly or all the self-doubt and the UNGODLY amounts of trolling they receive. Everyone's emotions are genuine, and despite the eloquency of Jonathan Blow or the rougher-than-sandpaper scenes of Phil Fish, these aren't scripted events. The movie can bring you to tears and have you cheering for games you may or may not already own.

As for the added commentary tracks, you get to listen to the director's commentary (or rather the production team's) and listen to them point out some neat factoids, as well as Team Meat. Just. Team Meat. If you bought the bundle for cheap, then the money is more than worth their commentary. The movie overall becomes a comedy, and at times, they're surprised to see scenes in the movie they don't remember being filmed. As caustic as their comments can be, they do so in a somewhat sibling-like jest for their fellow developers. The extra scenes get interesting because, well, Team Meat! They get commentary OVER that stuff as well!

To point some scenes out in the movie, the directors know how to film dramatic scenes that feel emotional. The positions of the cameras at times tell stories without the faces, such as the awkward foot section that shows the developers' wear over those months. Slice-of-life moments are sprinkled here and there to let the audience further explore the developers' lives, and shots of other games, whether or not they're specifically worked on in the movie, help change the visual pacing of the movie. In terms of audio, there is actually one part early on during Team Meat's commentary track where they rub up against the mic. There are no do-overs with commentary tracks since you're listening to the commenters (Team Meat in this instance) discussing the movie as they're watching it. No re-dos. No Takebacks. The directors have the decency to edit out monetary figures being thrown around though in these tracks, so it's not a simple record-and-paste job.

Oh, and if you're going for achievements, Indie Movie: The Game: The Movie is a nice way to learn up on some other indie games that aren't necessarily as popular, but it's not entertaining enough as a game. It does its job though in teaching you different games, but because it's in one artist's style, it may get confusing to see the art. Look up some of those games though, because a few are free and not necessarily a platformer.

10518344.review:
Indie Game: The Movie isminden de anlayabileceğiniz gibi oyun değil. Yayımcı desteği olmadan oyun geliştiren kişilerin bu süreç içerisindeki hayatlarına, yaşadıkları finansal zorluklara ve beklentilerine odaklanılmış bir belgesel. Braid, Super Meat Boy ve FEZ geliştiricilerinin, geliştirme sürecinden oyunların yayımlamasına kadar yaşadıklarını içeriyor. Special Edition DLC ile de başka bağımsız oyunlarla ilgili kısa filmler ve ana filmdeki geliştiricilerin yayımlanma sonrası yaşadıkları var.

Benim dikkatimi çeken FEZ'in geliştirme süreci. Görsellere aşırı odaklanılmış ve birden fazla yenileme yapılmış. Filmin ben de bıraktığı izlenimlerden bahsetmek gerekirse oyun yapmak için sadece kod bilmek yeterli değil. Yaratıcı bir hayal dünyası, düşündüklerinizi ve hissettiklerinizi resmedebilme beceresi gerekiyor. Sabırlı bir kişiliğe sahip olmalısınınz. Stres ve baskıyla başedebilmeniz gerekiyor. Empati yapmaya çalışıyorum da kusursuz oyun için dört yıl zaman harcasam ben katlanamazdım. Cidden bu insanlara saygı duyuyorum.

Filmde başarım sistemi var. Filmi izlemeye, yönetmenin yorumlarını dinlemeye başarımlar veriyor. Oyuncu olarak kendini tanımlayan her kişi mutlaka arşivinde bulundurmalı. Bağımsız oyunlarla fazla zaman geçiren bir insansanız, geliştirme süreçlerini merak ediyorsanız izlemelisiniz.

Один из лучших фильмов, обязателен к просмотру, 10/10.

Здесь показана психологическая сторона разработки игр одним-двумя людьми, т.е. разработки инди-игр. История создания шедевров инди-сцены, преподнесение зрителю всех эмоций разработчиков. На протяжении всего фильма зритель чувствует волнение или радость за того или иного разработчика, сопереживает им. 

При просмотре полностью погружаешься в рассказы разработчиков. Ярко выражается тема того, что инди-игры делаются с душой, не ради денег, только за идею.

Саундтрек к этому фильму, играющий на фоне, шикарный. Он не мешает, он приятный, он атмосферный.

One of my favourite movies of 2012 and of all time. This movie is cerebral and heart felt, I have not been moved by a movie in a long time. I think it just impossible to watch this and not feel something as these people work for years and years to achieve something that might not even happen.

The movie is also very well documented as it is all beautifully shot and topped off with an absolutely fantastic soundtrack by Jim Guthrie. The documentary takes place years before the games were released and gives us a look at their inspirations, struggles, and their success.

10494001.review:
Сегодня у меня было 200 рублей и передо мной стоял выбор - купить недостающие DLC для Saints Row IV или же купить Indie Game The Movie Bundle. Немного подумав, глянув на скидку этого Бандла в процентах и оставшееся время до окончания скидки, я-таки решил остановиться на последнем варианте...и я не пожалел.

Что же такое Idie Game: The Movie? Это документальный фильм (хотя, в нем есть психологическая доля) о 3-х разработчиках, которые пытаются через свои игры показать миру свой внутренний мир и чувства. Фильм интересен тем, что герои фильма делятся своими переживаниями, рассказывают о процессе создания таких игр, как Braid, Super Meat Boy, FEZ. 
   Некоторые моменты в фильме действительно задевают до глубины души - ты начинаешь сопереживать этим целеустремленным ребятам. Ведь посудите сами: эти ребята вложили все самое прекрасное и лучшее из своего внутреннего мира в данные игры, потратили кучу нервов на решение различных проблем и ситуаций и, несмотря на все трудности, ребята-таки показали миру свои игры и мир достойно их оценил.
   После просмотра фильма у меня было такое чувство, будто меня что-то вдохновило и, казалось, я даже мог бы свернуть горы: фильм очень сильно мотивирует, вдохновляет зрителя на сложные, казалось бы, вещи, он учит никогда не сдаваться и верить в то, что ты можешь преодолеть даже самые непреодолимые препятствия.

   Я остался очень доволен данным фильмом и, надеюсь, в Steam появится еще больше интересных и воодушевляющих документальных фильмов. Также меня порадовало то, что в данном Bundle есть те самые 3 игры, о которых идет речь в данном фильме: Braid, Super Meat Boy и FEZ. Думаю, мне будет во что поиграть и интереса к данным играм я не потеряю еще очень долгое время. Вперед к приключениям!

Оценка: 9.8/10

Most importat thing is, that indie gamedev is NOT only joyfull and beautifull coding-coffe-fastfood like procedure. It is full of pain, sadness, loneliness... to make a remarkable game requiers pure soul and pure heart.

To be honest, I glamorized the process of making a game. I glamorized it to the very moment of my first game-make attempt. It was 2 months ago, and my 1st game is plain s*it - but it is my game and it is complete. Then I realized, that developing a game hurts like hell, but I thought "Maybe there is something wrong in ME actually." Why am I saing this ? Because this movie makes me realize, that I was wrong. That there was no mistake nor problem with me - developing a game, regardless of its final form, its trully painfull... After all, like all creation processes, where Art comes out.

I have to thank for enlightening me to those guys in this movie. Great games gurus - creators of FEZ, Super Meat Boy and Braid. One day I shall stand in front of you with my own, ultimate game (which I plan to build with my friends) and salute you. One day, I shall thank you in person for what you teached me with this movie. One day... well, we will see, what the future holds.

片中的独立游戏制作人的出发点都各有不同，为了制作像童年玩的游戏那样能让人获得简单快乐的游戏，或是因为身体原因没有办法进入大型团队进行有压力的游戏创作（片中一个明显表明Super Meat Boy的编程Tommy患有糖尿病），亦或是不想与一个没有为自己游戏做出贡献的家伙利益分成。
    我相信每一个独立游戏制作人无论是出于什么目的，都希望能够看到自己的作品受到他人的认同，他们冒着有可能血本无归的风险，尽情泼洒着激情，编织自己的想象世界，努力为别人带去欢乐。
    感谢这部电影，没有它我可能不会知道躺在我游戏库里的这些“小游戏”是多麽的有趣，就以FEZ而言，光看到电影中的演示就让我看觉眼前一亮，像素画面所蕴含的新意，2D与3D的转换，让我看完之后就下载游戏玩了起来。
    大厂作品趋同化越来越严重，这些独立制作人的创意给在充斥着华丽的画面，震撼音效，宣传铺天盖地，成本动辄数亿数十亿的大作的包围之下。给了我们另外一种承载乐趣的形式，简单的东西也能带给我们快乐。

Quite simply, I would recommend this movie to anyone, hands down. 

We all hear about people working on games for years, the inevitable delays that occur, the show-stopping bugs, the passion of the developers, but watching this, at least for me, really hit the point home. Seeing the literal blood, sweat, and tears that these teams put into their games makes you realize their efforts on a whole other level; from seeing Team Meat desperately trying to finish Super Meat Boy in the month before release, to Jonathan Blow's anxiety over Braid being misinterpreted in reviews and Phil Fish's legal conflict over Fez, it personally was an eye-opener for me, truly putting a human face on the indie game dev scene.

Whether your a gamer or not, buy this. You won't regret it.

This is a great movie. I doesn't really overview the process of making the game, but instead the focus is on the idea of the struggles involved in releasing a game that already has hype built up. The movie also nicely shows the struggle of trying to balance creating something personal yet making it relatable outside your own head. There is also moments with Team Meat and Mr. Blow that show the pitfalls of a personal project you've worked on for years being over. Sometimes you get so close to the project you worked on that success and failure to your target audience doesn't matter any more. Being a more personal game is fine, but to get that close to a project can be dangerous.

10351214.review:
Я бы не сказал, что фильм шедевральный. Но и неплохой.
В нём отражена внётренняя часть разработчиков. Инди-разработчиков. Их мысли, их волнения и переживания, и знаете, я с дества мечтал сталть разработчиком игр, айтишником. Перехотел. И если у вас было такое же желание, что и у меня, я уверен, оно отпадёт и у вас тоже. Почему же? Сейчас я попытаюсь ответить.

Ладно уж разработчикам АС, им за ихнюю работу платят огромные деньги. А инди? Они не имеют инвесторов, пускай они и полностью свободны, но они работают, можно сказать, в одиночку, и создают шедевры. Самые настоящие шедевры. однако, если внимательно и углублённо понаблюдать за ними, то можно понять, что они чертовски волнуются. КАждый баг их игры отражается на них, каждый негативный отзыв, каждый негативный обзор. 

А как же давление? Или же, ажиотаж вокруг игры? Когда каждый орёт тебе "когда же она будет готова? Я уже жду не дождусь её релиза!", когда каждый буквально давит на тебя. И это отнюдь не приятно, а даже наоборот, это очень утомляет тебя со временем. Возможно ,в первые моменты вы будите рады тому, что на вашу игру обрнатили внимание, но потом это начнёт конкретно раздражать.

В этом фильме нет никакого экшона, нет перестрелок и боёвок. Это - история, это - судьбы. И не желающих смотреть такое сразу же попрошу отойти в сторону, только зря потратите свои "драгаценные 7 баксав". А если же вы любитель подобного жанра - милости просим, это кинцо специально для вас.

Фильм есть судьба и состралание, а не только экшн.

Геймдизайн и разработка видеоигр - часть их жизни, это то, с помощью чего они могут самовыразиться и показать свой внутренний мир. Не многие воспримут их творения положительно, но этого и добивается большинство инди разработчиков: неповторимость игровой механики, сюжета и многих других мелочей, делающих их игру неповторимой. Фильм - история, рассказанная несколькими разработчикам, об их триумфе, взлётах и падениях и способах достижения поставленной цели. Посмотрев этот фильм, начинаешь понимать, что мало просто желания, нужно посвятить себя полностью делу (для данных героев любимому) и пожертвовать чем-то большим чем просто свободное время. 9991222.review:
Indie Game: The Movie is a very well made documentary Kickstarted in 2010, released in 2012. The film follows three indie game developers at different stages of their game development.

The documentary gives viewers an insight into the indie game scene in North America, as well as the various difficulties faced by indie developers who finance the development of their games from their own pocket. 

Jonathan Blow's Braid was already a major success by the time the film was made, Team Meat's Super Meat Boy was soon to be released on Xbox Live Arcade, and the anticipated Fez was still not yet complete. We learn a little of the backgrounds, dreams, fears and motivations of these people. 

Commentary by Team Meat and the directors, beautiful music. DLC not too interesting, unless you wish to know a bit more of the controversies following Phil Fish after Fez was (eventually) released. 

TL;DR: Very good documentary that should be watched by anyone interested in indie game culture.

Overall a very interesting documentary, especially if you're interested in indie games and the work that goes into making them.

9782386.review:
Magnífico documental. Indie Game: The Movie no es una película sobre videojuegos, ni un estudio sobre esa ola de obras indie que ha revolucionado este arte; Indie Game es una reflexion coral sobre el miedo, sobre el rechazo social y sobre el fracaso. 

Resulta sorprendente escuchar a los protagonistas de estas emocionantes historias. Podemos decir sin titubeos que cada uno de ellos son genios. Genios de la informática, del diseño, del entretenimiento, pero sobre todo de la comunicación. Indie Game: The Movie muestra de forma notable la capacidad de expresión de los videojuegos, su entidad como lenguaje propio, pero sobre todo como un arte capaz de lograr que personas con serios problemas de socialización consigan conectar emocionalmente con millones de individuos en todo el mundo. 

Super Meat Boy, Braid, Fez... son pura elocuencia. Tanto en sus mecánicas como en su diseño artístico o en su narrativa, son un grito de liberación que paradójicamente contrasta con la terrible inhibición de sus creadores. Pero ante todo, son juegos que han cambiado y renovado un sector anclado en el mercantilismo más simplista, y que han conseguido abrirnos los ojos a miles de jugadores.

Si hay algo que destacar en los últimos años dentro de este arte, sin duda es la potente irrupción del sector indie. Muchos son los factores que han contribuído a este fenómeno, pero posiblemente el más importante de ellos es que un día, unas pocas personas decidieron contar al mundo sus miedos y sus anhelos en forma de píxeles y bytes. Sin ataduras ni presiones comerciales de ningún tipo; únicamente mostrando sus personalidades. Y como jugador, como amante de este arte, no puedo sino terminar esta modesta reseña agradeciendo y apreciando su genial esfuerzo.

Les debemos mucho a estos tipos.

9780310.review:
Die Geschichte der Indie-Spiele...
Dieser Film zeigt die Geschichte dreier Entwickler-(teams) sehr erfolgreicher und bekannter Indie-Spiele. Sie begleitet sie während des Entwiclungsprozesses zeigt Emotionen, Höhen und Tiefen der Mitwirkenden.

Un excellent documentaire qui revient principalement sur 3 jeux qui ont marqué le monde des jeux indés et leurs concepteurs !

Cela nous permet de prendre conscience que ce ne sont pas que de simples jeux, mais veritablement des "bébés", leur bébé,  et ils y mettent vraiment toutes leurs tripes malgré toutes les merdes et autres embuches qu'ils croisent et qui viennent nuir à leurs projets. 
C'est dingue de voir toutes les références aux jeux qui leurs ont donné l'inspiration (tous ces clins d'oeil dans Super Meat Boy :o ). Tout est vraiment pensé, et réfléchi.

C'est interessant de découvrir Phil Fish (que je connaissais essentiellement pour ses bad buzz) et surtout le génie qu'est Edmund McMillen *_*

Le DLC apporte des épilogues sympa et marrants sur chacun des protagonistes (mêmes s'ils sont non sous-titrés).

9655376.review:
Zajímá vás, jaké to je dělat hry, a co vlastně prožívají vývojáři v den vydání jejich díla?
Sleduje nezávislé (indie = independent) herní vývojáře (FEZ, Braid a Super Meat Boy) na jejich dlouhé cestě za slávou. Na cestě plné stresu, radosti a hlavně vášně pro hry.
Poznejte skutečné celebrity - lidi, díky jejichž kreativitě se můžeme každý den bavit, objevovat nové světy plné nových zážitků a hlavně prohlubovat svoji lásku ke hrám.
Pochopte, že za výbornou hrou nemusí stát obrovská společnost, ale i samotní jednotlivci. Jednotlivci, kteří do svých her dávají celé své srdce.
Usaďte se a sledujte napínavé životní příběhy, které se dějí dnes a do kterých se můžete zapojit i vy.

Skvělá hudba od Jima Guthrie (Sword & Sworcery LP) dodává filmu navíc fantasickou atmosféru.
Film, který je nesmírně inspirativní, ukáže kouzla herního vývoje všem, kdo se do něj na těch pár příjemných desítek minut ponoří.

Un excellent documentaire qui suit les papas des créateurs de Braid, FEZ et de Super Meat Boy. Loin des jeux AAA où des milliers de personnes travaillent sur un seul jeu, on voit comment une seule ou deux personnes essaient de créer des oeuvres plus personnelles et plus originales.
On les voit énormément douter, se remettre en cause, subir la pression des commentaires négatifs. Loin de tout angélisme, on se rend compte que créer un jeu indépendant demande énormément de sacrifices.
Un film extrêmement intéressant, sur une autre façon de faire le jeu vidéo. Primé au festival de Sundance en 2012.

В пример взяты разработчики трех одних самых известных игр, которые изменили представление об играх - Braid, FEZ и Super Meat Boy. Полтора часа отличного монтажа из моментов жизни создателей игр, из-за чего документалка смотрится на одном дыхании. Главные герои фильма - не игры, а люди. Люди, отказывавшиеся прогибаться под корпорации, чтобы передать свои мысли, идеи, переживания, частичку себя через игры. Люди, для которых будет лучшей наградой будет понимание со стороны игрока того посыла, что они пытались передать через игру, а не многомиллионные продажи и высокие оценки. Эту документалку определенно стоит посмотреть всем кто занимается разработкой, а также простым игрокам.

9580163.review:
The struggling artist is a trope that we're all familiar with, but most of us don't associate it with video game developers. That is pretty understandable because until 2009 or so the only games we saw were big-budget games being put out by large corporations. With the indie game scene exploding in the last few years, it became much more obvious that there were people making games purely out of passion; people who put their financial stability and reputations on the line to create something beautiful. And that's art.

Enter [i]Indie Game: The Movie[/i], a documentary that sets out to tell a few of these developers' stories. It focuses on Jonathan Blow ([i]Braid[/i]), Phil Fish ([i]Fez[/i]), and Edmund McMillen and Tommy Refenes ([i]Super Meat Boy[/i]). In the case of [i]Fez[/i] and [i]Super Meat Boy[/i], they interview the developers at several important points during the creation of their games. [i]Fez[/i] faced a very long development and legal issues that drained Fish. McMillen and Refenes had to crunch to get [i]Super Meat Boy[/i] out in time for an Xbox promotion. For all of them, the failure of their games would mean they would probably be finished with game development. [i]Braid[/i] was already out by the time the movie was filmed, so Blow mostly talked about what is important to him about independent development. It wasn't nearly as emotionally intense as the other developers' stories, but it helped to frame them.

Even the music was indie game related. Most of it was by Jim Guthrie, and a lot of it was taken straight from [i]Superbrothers: Sword and Sworcery[/i]. Being that I listen to that soundtrack on a fairly regular basis, it was pretty cool to hear them using the music in such an effecting way.

I was hoping that [i]Indie Game: The Movie[/i] would be the kind of documentary I could show my parents to convince them that game development is an art form, but I'm not sure it would work for that. The best audience are definitely gamers; those of us who are already invested in the indie scene will get a lot out of the movie, and gamers who have previously only been exposed to AAA games could be encouraged to expand their horizons. Obviously all three games that were featured have been successful and are very well-known, but during the credits they show many other indie games; even I hadn't heard of most of them, and you can bet I will be looking into them.

This movie is definitely worth a look for anyone who is remotely interested in video games.

9370275.review:
I just got done watching this movie, literally seconds ago. I had been told repeatedly, "Oh you gotta watch this movie, it's amazing. It'll change the way you view indie games."
I didn't expect those people to be as right as they were. 

This movie is about so many things. It's about making indie games, and about indie games in general. It's also about so much more. It allows you to see the rollercoaster of emotion that developers like Edmund McMillen had to go through, all the stress they had to put up with and how rewarded they were at how their game was received. It's about what was important to THEM about the game and how much of an extension of themselves the games really were. It's about what inspired them to do what they did, all the blood, sweat and tears that they put into their work. It gave me a indescribable amount of respect for these people and what they do, and it really touched me emotionally on several occasions throughout the movie.

Fucking watch this movie, you won't regret it.

9334275.review:
I got this as part of a bundle--otherwise I wouldn't have bought it.

This was an interesting documentary focusing on the troubles and insecurities of the indie game developers featured.

I might have enjoyed this film more if it showed both the highs and lows, but there were very few highs featured at all.

One really cute part was when one guy was super depressed, but then he watched a video of someone having a blast playing his newly released game, and he smiled and even laughed a little.

I realize the filmmakers were probably trying to paint a realistic picture of the challenges these guys faced and the stresses they were/are under, but it came across as a very dirty scene. When you watch the special features, you can see that it wasn't all doom and gloom, but that there were happy points and rewards that made all the hard work worthwhile.

(I actually liked the extras a lot more than the feature film.)

Also, by showing the game developers at their very worst, when they were stressed and under pressure and worried, they often came across as disturbed, arrogant, self-entitled pricks who don't give a bleep about anyone but themselves. Even the most normal of the bunch was never shown at his best, and I would have loved to hear more about his love and passion for game creation. Everyone's got a dark side, but maybe we can show the light as well?

This was an interesting documentary, but I do not recommend it.

9330108.review:
"Games are the ultimate art form, ultimate media,  it’s the total of every expressive medium of all time, made interactive." - Phil Fish

First of all, THIS ISN'T A GAME. This is a movie. Yeah, a movie on steam, ikr, but that's it. (That said there could be a mini game hidden somewhere in it... just sayin'...)
It follows some indie game creators: Team Meat (Super meat boy), Phil Fish (FEZ), and Jonathan Blow (Braid), during the important moments of their game developement and release.

The real core of that movie is the relation between these persons and their games. The way they identify themselves to these games, the way their games are basicly their life. Some of these guys go through big buisness issues (I'll try not to spoil), and are even talking about committing suicide or killing someone if they can't manage to release their game or create games anymore !

That's where you realise how Indie games are magic compared to "big companies games". They're made as a form of art and expression by a few peaple, whereas well... bigger games are made to reach the most peaple possible, that's that simple. Tommy Refenes and Phil Fish even talk about the way Modern Warfare is shit and modern Japaneese games aren't what they used to be.
Each one of the games presented in the movie are highly original: all the video game references and the gameplay of super meat boy, the crazy 2D / 3D thing of FEZ... etc. These guys didn't spend years of their life for nothing. 

The DLC really worth it too, many awesome docs are included into it (the way Ed McMillen reacts to internet trolls, the way the Super meat boy level designer got hacked, some zooms on other Team meat games that look almost even more original than their 2 must known games.. etc). But try not to watch everything in a row, cause they re-use the same fucking music everytime and it gets quickly annoying. 
 
If you like indie games, honestly, watch that movie, its absolutly awesome.

9313115.review:
Indie Game: The Movie is a fantastic documentary on the challenges faced by indie game devs and the pressures put on them by themselves and others. The title is a little misleading as this film doesn't actually focus on the creative process involved in coming up with an idea, fleshing it out, then developing that idea, with all the hiccups and walls along the way. Instead IGTM is more of a documentary on the game-makers themselves and what drove them to become game developers, neuroses and all. Then, they address what it's like preparing to release a finished product to the anticipating public - only to be beset upon by technical and/or social problems from all sides with all the stresses that come with. It's emotionally harrowing just to watch, let alone be actively involved in.

From a technical standpoint, the camerawork and audio is really great, the perspectives of the three different developers all synergise really well; and Team Meat's audio commentary track is just hilarious to listen to.

I wouldn't hesitate to recommend forking out the money to buy this. Sure, it's not a game, but that doesn't matter.
Buy it.

9206887.review:
[i]Indie Dev: The Melodrama[/i], err [i]Indie Game*: The Movie[/i] is a completely misleading title for an intricate human interest story documenting four developers in various stages of production (the so called overarching [i]'past, present and future'[/i] theme). 

It is an enjoyable experience which is a testament more to the circumstances of the subjects as well as the subjects themselves. Honestly, a documentary about a diabetic introvert, a morbidly hilarious husband, and an egoistical over-the-top guy seems not that hard to conceive. The vulnerability and candor managed to be captured on screen is very touching etc. and you connect with them on a real level... sure; which is sheer luck due to having such perfectly documentable(?) subjects with all their personal stories, histories and families conveniently accessible to the filmmakers. 

If Real Estate is about [i]'Location, location, location'[/i] I would say Journalism/making Documentaries is about [i]'Time, time, time'[/i] and they manage to be at right place at the right time to capture these genuine, raw, emotionally charged moments (like the swimming underwater with Ray-bans on thing! rrrright?). I guess this is why they completely changed their focus from documenting 'the indie dev scene' to these specific ones. Works for me!

Factor in a 'Morgan Freeman'-esque John Blow to neatly wrap up with a few words of wisdom/caution, and the palpable tension of the respective situations giving you an emotional story which could do well on The Oprah Winfrey Network.

Something with little to no actual technical information for a budding developer or dilettante but a very interesting story nevertheless. The Team Meat commentary is incredibly funny (although extremely profane) and deserves a second playthrough, the Director's one not so much but I did end up watching it as well.

P.S. Microsoft is evil, confirmed.

9097925.review:
This is a great documentary. It follows 3 sets of game developers, one approaching the release of their game, one still in the middle of development, and one after his game has released. It provides an objective, unbiased picture of it's subjects.

The title, however, is misleading. The movie purports to explore independent game development, and it does give the viewer enough context to understand the environment. Ultimately, this is not the focus of the movie. This is a movie about art and artists, particularly those who are good at making art but not at presenting it or reacting to what they've made. It shows how important emotional management is in the act of making art, before, during, and especially after the art itself is done.

That's not to say indie game development as a business is not worth exploring, but ultimately I think this movie choosing to be a character piece works to its benefit. I would and do recommend this to any artist I know, in any field--the lessons it teaches about creativity and introspection is applicable to any field, not just game development, and that is why it is such a good movie.

9096723.review: There is nothing more emotionally gratifying than to witness through crystal clear filmmaking the deeply personal aberrations and triumphs of a group of artists I admire and respect so greatly. Braid, Super Meat Boy, and Fez are not only my favorite video games, but to me they represent a new wave of honesty and purity in a thriving, endlessly growing art form. To see the stories behind the creators of such masterpieces so magnificently fleshed out in this documentary feels like a stroke of good luck on my part and a stroke of genius on Blinkworks part. Their heartfelt DIY production efforts and polished storytelling abilities display a side of new media that has yet to be grasped much at all by the mainstream. The games, the film, and the stories within are all perfect expressions of how the journey of true creators can at times be heartwrenching and painfully human. Highly recommended for anyone who is interested in artistic insight on all levels, especially non-gamers.

This is one of the best documentaries I have ever watched. Indie Game: The Movie is a documentary about 4 of the most famous and successful Indie game designers, and their stories about how they began and where they are today. Their stories are of hard struggles that hindered them and drove them into depression, and how they continued to create their games even when they were on the brink of complete failure and bankruptcy. 
All 4 stories are linked in the fact that, they all went through good times and bad times. But the main point that was seen in all stories was that these game designers are just one or to people. They kept saying that even if you don't belong to a major company or corporation, that if you put you're mind and entire being into it, you can create something that a lot of people will enjoy and love. 

This documentary was very powerful, Tommy Refenes said that you give up you're life to follow this dream, this passion. And if failure is you're reward then, all that time spent creating and developing a game was all for nothing. 

It's amazing to see and hear from these famous developer just where they started and how they got to where they are today. This is a marvalous documentary and I recommend it. Watch it.

8718364.review:
Note : 5/5 (N.B. : pour les mordus de Call of Duty ou de DotA… Allez jouer)
Indie Game : the movie est un film documentaire qui plaira assurément à toutes les personnes qui souhaitent voir autre chose que des making-of ou des carnets de développeurs où l’on a des art designer, des story-boarders et consorts vous servir pour la énième fois : « j’ai fait un super jeu, parce que j’ai fait ça, ça et ça, alors vous avez bien fait de l’acheter ou si ce n’est pas le cas, c’est sûr vous irez bientôt l’acheter ». Ce film vous propose des témoignages de ces personnes qui se cachent derrière des succès phénoménaux comme « Braid », « Super Meat Boy » ou « Fez ». Et quel plaisir d’avoir enfin des discours  et des actes qui témoignent de la sensibilité, des doutes ou des joies de ces créateurs de mondes imaginaires. Enfin des images qui nous montrent qu’être un développeur de jeu indé, c’est faire montre d’un amour inconditionnel pour ce support culturel qu’est le jeu vidéo, et qu’il faut être quasiment un joyeux illuminé pour aller jusqu’au bout d’un projet où l’on mise ni plus ni moins que sa vie au jeu de la roulette russe. Le créateur de jeu vidéo prend les mêmes risques, doit développer les mêmes talents que n’importe quel écrivain, peintre, musicien, cinéaste, etc., s’il souhaite être mise en lumière auprès du public et c’est en cela par exemple qu’il serait plus que temps d’affirmer que le jeu vidéo est le dixième art de l’humanité. Donc, merci Indie Game : the movie d’exister !

I loved this film. If you've ever wondered what it might be like to be an independent video game designer / creator / programmer, this is a definite must-watch.

8432759.review:
Indie Game: The Movie is a documentary that shows the process that indie game developers experience while creating and releasing their games. The documentary is amazing and causes so many different emotions while watching it - personally, I got goose bumps, I laughed, I cried, and I smiled. Watching this documentary really lets viewers feel a connection with the developers, and understand the pros and cons of what they do. Thought the final outcome may be rewarding because they made something of their own which they can relate to but they also sacrifice a lot to do so. To all the indie producers: Good job and keep producing great games! No matter how much I – we gamers may swear at you while we play, the experience and emotions are fun and entertaining. 

Disclosure: I may be a bit biased in this review as I love indie games and have helped out a friend with his indie game company but there is a lot of stress, grief and hurdles while producing a game which this documentary portrays quite well. I commend anyone who does it this, as well as recommend to anyone who is aspired to produce a game to do it and never give up – the rewards are worth it.

Game on! ❤

8421820.review: Documentaries are a booming, if flawed genre of film. They all too often fall prey to the tropes of the genre, feeling either too clinical or too emotional for the viewer to glean any information from them. Indie Game: The Movie falls into the latter camp. This does not detract from the film, though, as it is a film that is fundamentally about emotion. It is a glimpse into the mind of the troubled artists behind the games that we love. It is a sincere, and successful, attempt to give the viewer a glimpse into the mind of a designer and an understanding of what it means to be an artist. The love and dedication that one has for their work, the way in which the designers see their games as their own babies, the way these people’s work not only fills their lives but becomes them; all covered in the movie. This is one of my favorite documentaries, and even one of my favorite films, of all times. It is unblinking in it’s portrayal of the torture and suffering a creator of games, or any other medium, subjects themselves to so that their work can be subjected to the masses.

WARNING: this is not a game. And I don't mean that in a super-postmodern, hotly-debated-topic-of-recent-years, is-it-or-isn't-it-really-a-game, Dear-Esther-y kinda way. I mean...it's actually not a game. It's a movie. A really amazingly excellent documentary movie, with an awesome DLC to boot.  

   This is all about REAL LIFE, dude. Yeah, I know...I hate it too. But somehow, when it's someone else's life, and it isn't you experiencing all the trials and tribulations, and it's actually about some genuinely interesting people, some highly ARTISTIC people, unlike those fucking sex-crazed, crass yobs you see on Big Brother talking endlessly about sloppy knob-jobs in nightclub toilets...hell, this is some pretty compelling shit, ya'll. 

   You will laugh. You will cry. Well, I did anyway. Even on multiple viewings. AND I learned that I really, really like and sympathise with Phil Fish. Think you can't feel a kinship with Phil Fish? Watch this. AND the DLC material. You will be a better person. AND you will like Phil Fish. I like Phil Fish. And the other guys who made these games, but Phil's the one who seems to get the lion's share of the unfair criticism. Fuck all the Fish haters. You people should be fucking ashamed of yourselves.

   Waitaminute...is this a review or an impassioned debate in defense of Phil Fish?! Look, just watch the movie. Especially if you're interested in video games. Which I presume you are, if you're bothering to read this review, on Steam of all places. Otherwise, why are you here? Come to think of it...why are ANY of us here? I mean, on this Earth?! Oh Lord, I'm doing it again, aren't I? BAD philosophical contemplation...EVIL philosophical contemplation...DOWN, philosophical contemplation!! DO YOU SEE WHAT THIS FILM HAS DONE TO ME???

Verdict: 9.5/10.

8085197.review: DO NOT BUY!!!1! I know Indie Gaming (r) is in vogue right now, but this is an affront to that prestigious pantheon of games (stretching back through the ages to Braid). No gameplay to speak of whatsoever; I thought this would be like The Walking Dead, with QTEs and moral choices and that, but you literally don't have to press a button to progress - in fact, the only major command you have STOPS THE STORY ENTIRELY!  The narrative can be applauded for jumping about a bit, and they've created some entertaining characters, but it's handling of mutliple characters is no better than Donkey Kong 64s. It is linear, and I was offered no choices in the direction it went; the only significant decision I made that affected the rest of the narrative was to switch the game off. I for one am outraged that I got this for pennies off a Humble Bundle. This only gets 8/10.

7800866.review:
It's a bit biased of me to say, given my passion for video games, but Indie Game: The Movie is without a doubt one of the best documentaries I have seen in recent years! Yes, this is a movie on Steam, but that oddness in no way makes it any less worthwhile and actual is rather a good thing as it makes it easily accessible to the millions that use the service.

Though other games and developers are touched upon, Indie Game is by and large the story of three of the most acclaimed and outspoken indie developers of the last decade: Phil Fish (Fez), Jonathan Blow (Braid), and Edmund McMillen and Tommy Refenes of Team Meat (Super Meat Boy). Through the years leading up to the release of their respective games, Lisanne Pajot and James Swirsky's film offer a look behind the curtain at the trials and tribulations of independant game creation, and provides a welcome perspective to what at times can seem nothing but praise and accolades with little thought given to just how much work was required for these games to see the light of day.

What it does best though is show that these are just normal people doing what they love, and at the same time make it incredibly easy to relate to them. Given their often brass and controversial outward statements (Phil Fish perhaps most among them), it actually came somewhat as a shock to see them in a more personal light away from the press, while learning their stories which were both engaging and even heartwarming having grown up with similar experiences. It's no understatement to say my opinion of them as both creators and persons was drastically changed, and I feel those so quick to anger at what they may have said in the past really ought to take the time to watch this first.

Whether you are a gamer or not (though I'm guessing you are, given where this is posted), Indie Game: The Movie deserves your attention. It's a fascinating look at indie game development and those involved with it, not to mention fantastically edited and accompanied by a great score by indie favorite Jim Guthrie. It won't take much of your time, but could very well completely change your outlook on this medium we all enjoy so much.

5574718.review:
Огромный плюс данного фильма в том, что он кажется очень искренним. В частности, это ощущение усиливается за счет обстановки, окружающей этих людей: заваленные столы, комнаты с кучей непонятных вещей, общий бардак, обычные улицы, люди, эмоции и взаимоотношения без преувеличенной красоты и пафоса.

Основная идея фильма: создание игры - форма самовыражения, на ровне с книгами, картинами, кино и другими видами искусства.

Четко обозначен высокий риск, связанный с независимыми проектами. Годы жизни, потраченные впустую, подорванное здоровье, расшатанные нервы, потеря контактов с людьми... А в награду - провал, ничто. Вдобавок к этому на тебя подают в суд.

Фильм пропитан духом фриланса. Работаешь на себя, как хочешь, когда хочешь. Но при этом постоянная борьба со своей ленью, своими страхами, глупые ошибки, которые некому исправить, области деятельности, в которых ты ничего не понимаешь... И все же такой образ жизни кажется гораздо привлекательнее, чем работа в большой корпорации, где многие вещи уже продумали за тебя, а творческий процесс сводится к расстановке предметов в органайзере и приклеиванию цветных стикеров к монитору. Это обманчивое обобщение, не все так плохо в корпоративной среде.

Если подумать, то данные люди, по сути, - один из примеров торжества гуманизма, потому что они живут самореализуясь, а самореализация - цель их жизни. Правда, это звучит как-то странно.

5652654.review:
日本よ、これがゲームだ。

---
インディーゲーム開発者の私生活や開発中の悪戦苦闘に焦点を当てたドキュメンタリー映画。
いろんな有名インディー開発者（よく知らないけどそうらしい）の人もところどころ出てくるが、話の本筋としてはSuper Meat Boy作者の二名様およびFez作者のPhil Fish大先生のゲーム開発中の苦悩や失敗といった内面、そして成功までの道筋を赤裸々に描写した、という感じ。
どのようにゲームを作っているのかとか、何を考えてこういう作りにしたのかというような話も当然出てくるが、個人的にはあまりピンと来なかったので何とも言えない。とはいえ、むしろ技術的な話を楽しむ人も当然いるだろうとは思う。
Steamで堂々売ってるがこれ自体はゲームではなくただの（絵合わせゲームのおまけつき）映像作品である。

SMBのコンビがいろいろというか主に金銭面で生活的に苦しい環境に置かれる中で、いかにも人情溢れるご家族や奥様に支えられるお話を展開しているところに条件反射的に感動させられるのはいいとして、個人的な見どころとしてはそれに対比する形で描かれているPhil Fishのクリエイターとしての孤独な戦いについてである。
自分のようなこの作品で初めて彼の名前を知ったような人間にも映画中の言動だけで彼の社会性に不安を抱かせるようなレベルで、いざお名前をGoogle検索してみれば案の定インターネットで叩かれまくりというのはなんというか心から哀悼の意を表したくなるが、同時にこういったどこか上手くいかないような人こそ、ということで彼の事業面・生活面両方での成功を応援したくなったのも事実である。

ともかくSMBすら持ってないインディーゲーム界隈に全く興味がなかった自分でも一つの映像作品として十分楽しめたということは伝えておきたい。そういう自分ですら楽しめたのだから、元ゲーやインディー界隈のファンであればいうまでもないだろう。

まあなにはともあれ、これ目当てでSteamから直接買うような人もあまりいないだろうとは思うけど、自分のようにいつだかのバンドルで入手してたり、あるいは今後のバンドルに入ってたりしたら、カード目当ての起動放置だけじゃなく2時間使って真面目に観てみても損はしないかもしれませんよ、というお話でした。

追記: Phil先生、Fez買ったよ！

단지 내가 관심있는 분야에 다큐다보니 보게 된거긴 하지만 
너무 회의적인  인디게임 제작자들의 시선에  대해서 참으로 안타깝게 생각한다.

대부분이 보니 그다지 유복하거나 행복한  집안과는 거리가 멀고
사용하는 어휘나 태도를 봤을 때 고등교육을 받았다고 보기 힘들고
자살 위험이 있을 정도에 심각한 우울증 증세를 볼 때는 좀 안타까웠다.

이런 정상적인 애들에 비해서 몇가지씩 떨어지는 일종의 사회적 낙오자들이

모습은 행복과는 상당히 먼 거리가 있어 보였다.

당뇨병에 걸렸는지 인슐린 주사를 맞고 있는 제작자, 땡전한푼 없어서

마지막 발악을 보는 것 같아서 소름끼치고 기분 나쁠 정도 였다.

========================================================

라고 적을려고 했는데 이거 감독이 너무 깔끔하게 잘 만들어서
이 루저 새끼들 참 멋지게 잘 찍어둔거 같다. 솔직히 게임제작자의

2033478.review:
Main Feature:
A candid look into indie game development.  We follow Edmund McMillen and Tommy Refenes of Team Meat through uncertain times during the development of Super Meat Boy. From the insane three month crunch to finish their project to Microsoft's careless handling of their release, it's a harrowing journey.  We also follow Polytron's Phil Fish and the drama spiral that surrounds him.  He struggles to release Fez, his passion project in development for nearly 5 years, despite a bevy of roadblocks.  Like him or hate him the film provides an honest look at the personal difficulties and pressures that affected the game's turbulent development. Fish seems open and vulnerable here, far separated from the man making headlines for inane, egotistical comments.  There are also interviews with other indie developers, such as Jonathan Blow (Braid) who provides some unique insight into the indie movement and how developers try to connect meaningfully with their audience.

Extras:
The extras include some mini-featurettes showing details of the film's production, trailers, a few interviews with other indie developers, and a Super Meat Boy featurette.  But by far the greatest extras are the two commentary tracks.  The developer's commentary provides lots of interesting technical information about the film, behind-the-scenes exclusives, funny anecdotes, and more.  It adds a ton of new information worthy of a second viewing.  The second commentary is done by Edmund and Tommy from Team Meat and it is absolutely hilarious as they riff and joke with each other while watching themselves on-screen.  It is highly entertaining and especially great to see their sense of humor come out despite the somewhat dark and depressing nature of the film.

Special Edition:
The special edition adds epilogues for the featured developers to see where they are now.  There are also featurettes showcasing some of the criticisms they have received, such as Phil's infamous commentary on Japanese games, and featurettes on Braid, Edmund's other games, and a number of other indie games like Spelunky.  There's over 100 minutes of extra content as well as a hidden game to play.  Team Meat returns with their hilarious commentary on all the new footage and it is just as entertaining as their previous commentary.  This edition adds Steam achievements and trading cards.

Limited Edition Blu-Ray Box Set:
Only available directly from the IGTM website. This includes everything above, a Steam key for IGTM + Special Edition on Steam, a bunch of physical extras, and an exclusive bonus disc. The extra disc adds about 2 more hours of content, including the entire GDC interview panel. There is also a director Q&A from a film screening and a featurette where the directors explain how the movie was made. Finally, there are 8 new developer interviews, including a lengthy discussion with Edmund McMillen about The Binding of Isaac.

1436288.review:
These days, games are cheap as (or even cheaper than) chips. You can buy them with a few clicks of the mouse. Reviews and opinions and recommendations and whatnot are everywhere.

It is kind of easy to forget sometimes that these games are the products of someone's blood, sweat and tears. Indie Game: The Movie is a fantastic reminder of what all this gaming lark means to the people on the other side of the fence: the creators, the artists, the idealists. The ones who put their entire lives on the line to make something they have always wanted to make, without knowing whether their vision would be welcomed by the public with a warm embrace or boos and hisses.

Also: Jim Guthrie's soundtrack is utterly out of this world and, in a way, makes it hugely disappointing that the film itself doesn't cover the story behind the fantastic Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP.

5245688.review:
100分程度のドキュメンタリー映画。主にSuperMeatboy,FEZ,Braidの3ゲームの作者にフォーカスしながらインディーゲームの開発に密着するという内容。インディーゲム開発の夢と希望と現実を描いた良作です。カードドロップ目当てで見始めたものの、非常に興味深い内容で楽しめた作品。日本語字幕もあるので、インディーゲームや映画好きの人にもおススメ。

本編の中でBraid作者のJonは語る。「大企業のゲーム作りでは"角"を削る。何故なら多くの人々に楽しんでもらわなければならないから。一方でインディーのゲーム作りは異なる。個人の芯の弱さや欠点までもゲームに入れ込みチャレンジする。」この言葉を「大手とインディーじゃ予算も違うし、マーケティング的には当たり前だよね」、「他の業界でも通じそうな教訓」等と頭で理解するのは簡単。
しかし本編で登場する開発者達はゲーム作りを自己実現そのものとして、まさしく命懸けで開発に携わっている。信念を持ち、全身全霊を賭して開発に打ち込む姿は鬼気迫るものがあり、人、物、金、諸々のリソースがほぼ無い崖っぷちに立ちながらも、開発に没頭する彼らは尊敬に値するし一見の価値が有る。

己の全てを注ぎ込んだゲームは自分そのものであり、市場下されるゲームの評価は、開発者その人自身の評価でもある厳しい現実。本作で紹介された3作は誰もが知る程有名なゲームであり、開発者達は勝利を収めた成功者だが、インディーゲーム開発の裏には何百倍、何千倍、もっと沢山の敗者がいるのだろう。バンドルを購入する時にはも少し払う金額を上げてみるか、と思わされた作品。

1023471.review:
Der Dokumentarfim [i]Indie Game[/i] entführt den geneigten Zuschauer hinter die Kulissen der Indie-Szene, einer in den letzten Jahren hochgeprisenen Subkultur der Spielebranche. Doch jenseits von Glanz und Gloria der Mainstream-Presse lauert einie ganz eigene Welt zwischen Freude, Schmerz und kompromissloser Leidenschaft für das Medium Videospiele.

Die bekanntesten Auftritte sind Jonathan Blow, Team Meat und Phil Fish - passionierte Entwickler, doch auch geplagt von Problemen und engen finanziellen Möglichkeiten. Der Film zeigt tatsächlich wie weltfremd so mancher Indie-Entwickler ist, der bereits Jahre an seinem Projekt arbeitet und eine gewisse Nähe aufgebaut hat. Ängste vor Verlust und vernichtenden Kritiken sind eine konstantes Thema und Spiele wie [i]Fez[/i], [i]Super Meat Boy[/i] & [i]Braid[/i] tragen ein Stück ihrer Macher in sich.

Weit weg von lobenden Presseartikeln und weiter weg von großen Produktionen ist [i]Indie Game[/i] ein faszinierender Einblick in die kleine Welt der Indie-Entwickler. Bild- und Tonqualität sind sehr gut gelungen. Das Bonusmaterial ist ebenfalls sehenswert.

Ever since I first saw this movie, it has been my favorite movie of all time. Before I watched this movie, I thought, "I wanna be a game dev at some big comany!" This game inspired me to be an indie dev. I don't want to deal with someone else's project if I can't have creative say and get shot down because a corporate influence says no. FUCK THAT NOISE. I'd rather make my own game and make it exactly that. MY GAME. I don't wanna make some corporate douche-bag wealthy on my ideas, that sounds about as frustrating as knowing that somewhere, someone's being paid for the music John Lenon wrote more than 4 decades ago. Getting paid for a dead man's work is wrong to me. Fuck, getting paid for anyone else's work other than your own is wrong to me, hence my interest in making an indie game. Something like Steam taking a cut for advertisement and hosting is different, I'm talking about you getting the minority of the pay for doing the majority of the work while some ass-hat gets paid millions for just telling people to go fuck themselves on a daily basis.

tl;dr: this movie's awesome, go buy it, or at least watch it on netflix.

第一次写评论，不喜勿喷。
一部长达差不多两个小时的电影，阐述了独立游戏制作者生活的点点滴滴。
说实话，我不太了解独立游戏，但当我看完这部电影之后，我心中产生一种敬意，一种对独立游戏制作者的真心的敬意。他们跟我想象的不一样，我之前认为他们也是拥有一定资产的人，但不是的，他们当中有些人甚至很贫穷，一部独立游戏承载着他们的梦想，甚至是生命。他们跟那些商业化程度高的公司不一样，他们花上几年打造一部独立游戏，只为了他们追求的东西，他们所希望的东西。他们令人感动，他们做游戏的精神值得所有游戏制作者借鉴和学习。他们才是真正懂得什么才是游戏的人。他们挖掘游戏，他们承受着常人不能忍受的煎熬，他们让人们知道游戏制作者的不易。无论是Braid，SuperMeatBoy，FEZ还是其他独立游戏都倾注了制作者所有的心血，大公司亏一个游戏还不至于死，可是对于独立游戏制作者而言，这可能是一种灾难。独立游戏制作者值得我们去尊敬，去了解，去支持。
独立游戏本身不是神作，独立游戏制作者才是活在现世的“神作”。向所有游戏制作者致敬。

6520410.review:
«Цена независимости»

Braid, FEZ, Super Meat Boy — не просто игры. Игры созданы для того чтобы в них играли, верно? Но что если вся игра сделана одним человеком для одного человека? Человеком, решившим вывернуть поток своего сознания наизнанку и показать свой внутренний мир всему миру? Вероятно, наткнувшись на непонимание или того более — полное отторжение. 
Я смотрел данный фильм на одном дыхании. Я давно не ощущал столь глубокого контакта со зрителем, подобно тому, как независимый разработчик говорит с игроком через свои творения, идя на большие жертвы в надежде получить большую награду — не просто хорошие продажи, не просто отличные оценки, а осознание вложенного вместе с осколком души смысла.
Этот фильм не о инди-играх — он о людях, которые их делают. О жертве, которую они приносят. И о части себя, которую отдают.

- Что будет, если вы не сможете завершить игру?
- Я убью себя. Вот мой стимул её завершить. Потому что тогда я смогу не убивать себя.

5327644.review:
A 94 minute documentary movie that you'll like if you played Braid, Super Meat Boy and Fez.

It's not only about the games, but most importantly about the people behind the games: how these indie developers suffer, cry, stay awake, feel emotional pain and work hard to fulfill their dream of transform an idea into a game.
After watching this movie, I feel like I'd know them in a deeper way, their strengths and their flaws, because they're simple humans like you and me, even if we often tend to idolize them.

Some quotes:
- "What would happen if I can’t finish the game? I will kill myself." Phil Fish
- "If you don't see a vulnerability in somebody, you're probably not relating with them on a very personal level." Jonathan Blow
- "I love him, but it's hard to stay together as a couple. Sometimes I know he's in the same room only because I can see his back." Danielle, Edmund McMillen's wife

This movie is up and personal with the small indie developers of games such as Super Meat Boy, FEZ and Braid. That said, this is but a mere snap shot of the process. Some of these games had been in development for several years already. It's not at all a technical documentary, but more of a personal diary, where you get to witness their frustrations, their ups and downs, as they work on their game.

If you dabble in development and know how working on a tight deadline feels like, if you are an aspiring game developer, or if you are simply interested in indie gaming and are curious about how it works behind the scenes, this movie is for you.

686314.review:
This documentary is a must-see to anyone even slightly interested in personal videogame development.  It follows the story of three indie developers on their path to making their games, although you already know how their games turned out at this point since we're way in the future compared to when the documentary was originally released.  Basically it's the story behind the guys that made Braid, Super Meat Boy, and Fez, and recounts all the trials and tribulations that these developers had to go through for making their games into a reality.

A lot of what they said (especially Ed's scenes) really struck me in the heart, because you can really tell they are pouring their heart and soul into their games, but it's just that you don't really have a clearer view than what you see in this documentary as it's recording them as they first released their games, not knowing if it was going to be a flop or passable or the next big thing.

What a lot of people don't see past this documentary is to fathom just the sheer amount of indie developers that didn't make it in the industry, to the point where you have never even heard of some of their titles.  As someone who does eventually want to make their own game, no matter how big or how small I'm planning it to be, this documentary really showed me a glimpse of how much sacrifice you need to gamble on making a game.

1444056.review:
A brilliant insight into the lives of indie game developers and all the troubles they face. 

It's a really heartwarming look into how hard it is to work in a small team, then have all that stress, hard work and effort be validated when they see it has paid off once it's released.

A highly recommended watch if you're a fan of the indie games community.

4463912.review:
For anybody that's into gaming, coding, or graphic design; this is for you. This movie talks about the intricacy of coding that these developers put into their games, and the art and themes that are packed into them. It also covers three of the best rated games of the past four years or so, so that's another reason for gamers to watch it. Just remember, if you're not a fan of cussing or provocative language, and get completely outraged at peoples opinions that differ from yours, this movie may torque you off at times. 

 It's definitely my pick for best documentary of the year, possibly even my favorite overall movie of the year. An incredible emotional experience along with incredible cinematography combine to make it a move that grabs you and doesn't let go. I've watched it several times over (in various formats), and the journey that the three developers go through never faltered in making me reevaluate how much I appreciate the work put into things. The music by Jim Guthrie is also incredible, and really adds to the whole experience. 

A must watch, either buy it on Steam (or any other format), or watch it on Netflix. However, if you want special features and a wide array of subtitle options, then you definitely should buy the Steam/Website version.  Completely worth the money I paid for it.

I'm a huge fan of both documentaries and indie gaming so when this became availible as part of the Humble Bundle it had me reaching for the ol' bankcard before I'd even seen the other games included. I've always been interested into the development aspect behind games but hadn't really researched it in any depth and aside from the childhood dreams of one day making games for a living I really didn't know much about development. This movie interviews some of the most prominent people in the Indie Game movement there's the creator of Braid, the creators of Super Meat Boy and the creator of the long awaited title Fez. It shows the sheer turmoil these men put themselves through in-terms of working ludicrously long hours trying to create the next build of their game or even just trying to squash bugs that have been putting their stress levels at all an all time high for months. This documentary had me totally captivated from start to finish and I highly recommend you give it a watch.

Everything about this film is thought out well.
The framing is excellent, the progression of the devs stories are well thought out and most importantly, you feel like you're part of their plight. 2078438.review:
趁着感恩节的折扣，终于入了这部属于游戏列表的电影。影片讲述了3个极其成功的独立游戏的开发故事，不像那些大作的花絮是一个可有可无的附庸品，如果你喜欢独立游戏，那么本品是绝对不可以错过的。看完之后你可能会为自己曾经全价购入了某款作品感到欣慰，也会为自己渐渐成为了一个1刀党，将那些属于某个人的心血的作品作为纯+1的工具而感到汗颜，你甚至会想要重新玩玩某个游戏，希望可以得到更多的感悟。独立游戏和那些大公司的作品不同，如果你觉得不喜欢，真的不要再轻易的用上“垃圾”这样的词汇了。
这不是一部励志电影，看完之后你不会有想要真的去独立开发一款游戏的冲动，但是绝对会教会你什么是尊重。
看到Phil迷茫无助的表情，Edmund和他老婆眼中的泪水，Tommy的疲惫，不知不觉，我也眼眶湿润。

Fantastic movie looking into the motivations, trials and uniqueness that is indie game making. It mainly follows Team Meat and Phil Fish as they push Super Meat Boy and Fez to completion and first public demo respectively. 3456075.review:
An exquisite documentary. Filled with passion, optimism, pessimism, blowhards, true believers and artists and everything in between. Unflincihing and honest in the best possible way, never once shying away from showing the less admirable sides of the subjects, nor trying to portray them as something they aren't. 

Beautifully crafted and impeccably paced, Indie Game: The Movie also can boast itself as one of the most beautiful documentaries to come along in a long while. While some shots do feel a bit show-offish, it is, for the most part, truly marvelous to look at. 

Unresevedly recommended for everyone, everywhere. Even those not interested in gaming.

Meu Deus ! Sensacional !
Primeiro de tudo por poder assistir pelo Steam, sensação ótima ! Poder compartilhar um filme sobre games com seus amigos.
Enquanto eu assistia 2 amigos me chamaram perguntando sobre o filme e eles acabaram optando por comprar.

Retrata sobre o acompanhamento do desenvolvimento (nada MUITO detalhado) e lançamento de Super Meat Boy e FEZ, com alguns comentários do criador de Braid.

Acho que o filme afirmou muita coisa do que eu já pensava a respeito de games e apresentou o lado do desenvolvedor indie, que passa por problemas que qualquer um do nos podemos passar. Fora a dificuldade, mesmo sendo indie, para lançar o jogo.

Recomendo !
Acho que qualquer um que se considere gamer, deveria assistir esse filme. E na boa? Ao menos comigo, reforçou a ideia de que piratear um jogo ou qualquer outra coisa, pode acabar destruindo sonhos ! Pensem nisso ! ;)

2187383.review: [Will write a more comprehensive review]. Anyway: Quick rundown of my immediate reaction: Would REALLY liked to have seen more focus directed toward the history of 'indie games' as a whole, rather than just the personalized tales, foibles and triumphs of the creators (though that was very interesting, I should mention). All in all, I enjoyed this documentary, but I wouldn't necessarily recommend this to anyone not already interested in the topic (specifically non-gamers), because the film direction only gave the viewer(s) a cursory view of indie games. I think this film was more of a pick-up-and-go biopic than a pull-back-the-curtain kind of piece, yet it still manages to captivate, even inspire. With that said, I still enjoyed this and was glad Steam is showcasing it. Major, major props to the game creators and team of documentarians who put this together. More later- I need to digest, view again, then write again.

It's nice to see the actual "people" behind the development of independant games. Not the actual development process but the lives, the trials and the tribulations of developing a game without the backing of a large publisher, the stress, relationships, the joy of getting it published and passing all the stressful stuff. This may be not for you if you want to see how to make games, but if you're interested in what it takes to make a game on your own or what kinds of things affect the game development (both ideas and events) then this is a definite no-brainer.

Even if you aren't interested in seeing behind-the-scenes, it's a very heartwarming and gut-wrenching story of 4 indie-devs. A must see in my opinion.

I never knew you could make such a beautiful movie about indie games, worth every little penny.

2723132.review: This is a documentary that follows the journeys of indie game developers as they create games and release those works, and themselves, to the world. It really goes in depth with how an indie game is developed and what the developers have to go through to make a game that we will all enjoy. This move delivers an awesome 1080p HD crystal clear picture which is awesome to watch. The story is captivating and really interesting to watch. It follows 3 games through their development which are  Super Meat Boy, Braid and FEZ,  The overall movie was very well done and I have enjoyed watching it , with commentary it goes more in detail about each situation and helped me to find out more about what happen in those times of production. The only downfall in this movie is that it does drop the F*word alot and freely.  After watching the movie there is more to explore with the extra content that is available on the main menu.This movie is very inspiring and I highly recommend this movie to any gamer.

169897.review: Creation from the heart. That's what this movie is about, and it captures it. I love documentaries, and I know they are not for everyone, but if you love games you should watch this.

811500.review:
Indie Game The Movie shows exactly how hard and tough the lives of indie game developers can be. Let's be honest, we all take these developers for granted. Ever since the release of Braid, one of the first commercial and financially successful games, there's been a crazy amount of new indie games and developers. 

But what drives these developers, and at what cost ? Indie Game The Movie shows just that. Indie developers shouldn't be compared to big studio companies. It would be easy to do that, but it would also be unfair to these people. These developers all show that it requires an incredible amount of dedication, passion and - sometimes - even isolation to work on their game - AND finish it. It's not just about the money; these games are something personal. And, as gamers, we get the chance to find out what that something exactly is or could be.

A great documentary that all serious gamers should see.

[Rating: 80/100]

2308208.review: Amazing, pretty much a perfect representation of what it's like to work as an indie.

1213901.review:
Really good documentary about indie game development. Focuses more on few individuals/teams than the whole scene and it's history, but still good watch. Give it a go :9

Edit:

Still a damn good watch, and the extra stuff that comes with the Special Edition adds nicely to the flick.

Also, do yourself a favour and watch it all with Team Meat commentary track enabled - you won't regret it!

Re-Edit: Just wanted to point out to few who's been flabbergasted of my 56 hours with this thing - I just roll the playlist with Team Meat commentary on as substitute podcast. Those fuckers are super fucking funny!

666575.review:
Games can be art...they can be transcendent and rise to something...different than just "art". Maybe not "better" than traditional art...looking at most non-interactive art is passive and mental and can lead to an emotional experience. But there are moments in some games where you hit all those descriptive adjectives and through the tactile manipulation of your character you achieve an amazing sense of accomplishment as well. 

This movie tells the story of a few independent developers and the emotional experience each went through trying to get their game published. It's much more than a "gaming" movie...it's really nothing more than people pursuing their dreams and allowing all of us to share in them. It's really a great little movie about a few little great games and the souls who built them.

Personal note: I've done a little of this in my past making levels for a game my son started and I have to say on a really small scale, I completely understand what these guys went through.

5046065.review:
Ever wonder about the Individuals behind the Indie games available?
They are real people, a little bit crazy, a little bit quirky, and all human. They're not conglomorates, they're not highly funded, and they sacrifice a lot to make their ideas into a reality.
This is a great movie about the People behind the game.

320529.review:
This well-crafted film is for everyone. If you enjoy playing games, following the industry, support indie development, know someone who cares about these things, or even simply appreciate real stories of dedication, perseverance, heart-ache, conflict, and inspiration, you need to sit down and watch this.

There should be more documentaries like this about this subject. Despite what some publishers and massive developers may want you to think, the individuals are what make up the world of gaming and there are clever, funny, touching personalities that drive it all.

Buy it and watch it. Now.
